metadata.titleEn: LA-ICP-MS data of pyrite from Hengdong cobalt deposit in northeastern Hunan
metadata.description:
The dataset includes the data of laser ablation plasma mass spectrometry (la-cip-ms) of pyrite in Hengdong cobalt deposit, Hunan Province. The experimental methods are as follows: the analysis was completed in the National Geological Experiment and testing center, and the analytical instrument was Finnigan element 2 ICP-MS with nwr193 nm laser ablation system. In the experiment, helium was used as carrier gas, and the diameter of laser spot was 35 μ m. The pulse frequency is 10 Hz, the laser energy is 80%, the analysis time of each point is 60 s, including 20 s background test and 40 s sample signal. The tested elements include 34S, 57Fe, 59Co, 60Ni, 65Cu, 66zn, 75as, 82se, 96Mo, 107ag, 115In, 118sn, 121Sb, 208Pb, 209bi, etc. The USGS sulfide standards mass1, nist610 and nist612 were used as the combined external standard, kl2g (one of the silicate standard series mpi-ding) as the monitoring standard, and the Fe content analyzed by EPMA as the internal standard. The data can be used for geochemical analysis of Hengdong cobalt deposit in Hunan and similar deposits in Northeast Hunan.
The above data have been published in SCI high-level journals, and the data are true and reliable. The data is stored as a word document.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in word document format without special data format and numbering instructions.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze trace elements in pyrite from cobalt ore deposits using LA-ICP-MS technology?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to analyze trace elements in pyrite from cobalt ore deposits is the use of LA-ICP-MS technology, where the analysis is conducted at a national geological laboratory. The method involves using a Finnigan Element 2 ICP-MS plasma mass spectrometer equipped with a NWR193 nm laser ablation system. Helium gas is used as the carrier gas, with a laser spot diameter of 35 μm, a pulse frequency of 10 Hz, and 80% laser energy. Each analysis point includes 60 seconds of measurement time, comprising 20 seconds for background testing and 40 seconds for sample signal acquisition. The trace elements analyzed include elements like 34S, 57Fe, 59Co, and others. Calibration is done using USGS sulfide standards MASS1, NIST610, and NIST612 as external standards, and KL2G as a monitoring standard, while Fe content from electron probe analysis is used as an internal standard.

Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of employing LA-ICP-MS analysis for pyrite samples in cobalt mineralization studies in northeastern Hunan is to provide reliable geochemical data that can facilitate the understanding and exploration of similar mineral deposits in the region. This data aids in the geochemical analysis of the Hengdong cobalt deposit and supports broader geological research in the area.

Enablement.Question: What technological methods and equipment are essential for capturing detailed trace element data in pyrite samples from cobalt deposits?
Enablement.Answer: The use of LA-ICP-MS (Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry) is essential, employing a NWR193 nm laser ablation system coupled with a Finnigan Element 2 ICP-MS plasma mass spectrometer. The method involves using helium as a carrier gas, a laser spot size of 35 μm, and a pulse frequency of 10 Hz with 80% laser energy. The analysis time for each point is 60 seconds, including background and sample signal testing.
